text: Maybe try Angrist and Pischke "Mastering Metrics" - it's focused on quasi linear models (difference in difference, regression discontinuity, instrumental variables) but I think does a move job getting the basics across with some more mathematical detail in appendices formalising some of the ideas. They also have "Mostly Harmless Econometrics", which covers the same topics but in slightly more detail (they say it's more targeted at grad students)

text: I don't have any specific quotes to hand but he kind of makes it sound like no one ever thought of trying to use statistics to do casual inference. As an economist I only ever learned statistics as econometrics, in which to a first approximation people don't care about much else than parameter identification in a casual sense, dealing with unobserved heterogeneity that might introduce bias etc (that's what the Angrist and Pischke book summarises). Now it might be that things were quite different in statistics departments in the 1980s or so, I wouldn't know, but it reads a bit odd

text: <@U7JQGPGCQ> - interesting to hear! I agree - he does seem to dismiss all other efforts as being trivial or flat out wrong. I think that where Pearl's thoughts really shine is when he emphasizes the do-calculus for fine-grained analysis of causal scenarios (i.e. the smoking debate in the 1960's). Did you have much of an opinion on the do-operator?

text: I think I'd need to read the actual more academic texts for that rather than The Book of Why which is targeted at a broader audience. Again it seems to me that the "do operator" is conceptually the same as a potential outcome in Rubin's classic framework (which is from the early 70s!), but I haven't seen its usage in any formal setting so it might enable some formal proofs that would be hard to do otherwise?

text: Well, I've read the book right before starting my masters in Applied Math, and I was a bit discouraged  by the lack of interest of mathematicians in Causal Inference (at leas when I talked to my professors about it, just one of them had slight interest about it and used it, and actually the department of Economics seemed more interested). When I read the book, it really sounded like a golden idea, with tons to explore (perhaps it still is), but I guess after it's invention, still not much really impactful stuff have come out of it. At least, not that I've heard of.
